ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course focused on the Russian legal system, so I became a lot more knowledgeable about Russian law and human rights; however, the course also taught me more generally about legal scholarship, international law, the role of NGOs in the human rights space, and much more!
I learned about Russian politics and protest movements. I also learned a bit about human rights law more generally and about research methodologies.
Learned a lot about Russian history and the legacies of communism in the country. The focus on socio-legal studies was absolutely fascinating.

How to approach political science through a qualitative analysis perspective as opposed to the typical quantitative analysis most dominant in the field. It was a very humanizing approach to what can be a diminishing area of study. Very good and informative historical introduction to this transition from soviet to contemporary Russia and why we see the issues we do today-- how they developed and so forth.
I learned so so so much about contemporary human rights challenges in Russian as well as their historical foundations in czarist and soviet Russia.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: This was a really great course that covered a lot of material on the Russian legal system and Professor Mustafina was always very engaging. Weaknesses: It felt as though we fell into the same type of discussions over and over again at times, which may have just been a consequence of the interests of this particular class. Additionally, the session organization scheme sometimes was a bit confusing.

This course offered a very nice overview of Russian human rights movements from the Soviet period to today. The readings were generally interesting. In terms of how the course could be improved, it might be helpful to go more in depth into a few of the topics, as it sometimes felt that the sessions were a bit disconnected even though they were enjoyable and I felt that I learned quite a bit.
Maybe a bit more focus on comparative aspects with the American system, such as mass incarceration.

The reading responses were quite demanding but as the semester progressed they became easier-- because the language was more normalized. Could have used more guidance when writing the paper because it was easy to procrastinate and the course carried the assumption that students had written long research papers before, would not recommend this course as an introductory political science course.

I thought this course was excellent, it had the best reading assignments of any class I've ever taken-- always manageable in quantity and relevant in content. I thought our discussions were always informative and fun to participate in. There isn't anything I would change about this class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual seminars worked pretty well -- they were engaging and class discussions were facilitated well.
remained very engaging even virtually!
The weekly writing assignments, presentations, and discussions were all very well adopted to zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Professor Mustafina is truly very committed to helping students learn the material, I highly encourage you to meet with her during office hours because she is so knowledgeable about the course's topics!

Yes, if you're looking to learn about Russia and about human rights law more broadly, this class is worth taking. The workload was manageable, and the assignments were generally interesting to complete, i.e. I enjoyed researching modern issues in Russia.

I think this course is wonderful if you possess a niche interest, even if you do not know anything beforehand. Very difficult course if this is not a topic that sparks any type of interest. Be prepared for a different more qualitative type of political science as well.
Absolutely! I thought this class was great.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
n/a
We only met once a week over zoom.
